div1.p:
Dearest Jane - Your letter came this rainy noon with one from Uncle Art and as I'm in the mood for scribbling will dart off a few lines here on some cushions in front of the fireplace - Emily upstairs in bed reading Shakespeare - Evelyn down at Sevierville & coming back to this room - Aunt Lizzie knitting away on her stocking - and two of the school girls playing "Authors" in the corner. They are Veatrice Parton & Birthana McCarcter caught by the rain - Birthana is one of my special McCarters and a dear girl - She could have been home but some of the youngsters had been teasing her so that after school I found her crying & brought her home. We have our troubles in school of course - Abbie's girls are usually at the bottom too. The McCarter girls are so hard working & have such good stuff in them they will amount to something some day I know - Cora was here last week and you remember. This noon they all boys & girls too were playing "Farmer in the Dell" in the hall & having the best time. Two of the older girls practice at noon time - Most of them bring their lunches you know so that it's a lively place from
12 to 1 - Lucrettie Reagan gave me instructions when I left for lunch to hurry back so I could help her with U.S. History as she couldn't answer "nary a question". The little ones always are asking - "Is it time for books? (meaning school) When I ask a question in class many a time they will put up their hands & shake them violently saying under their breath - "Let me - let me!" I love my writing class of Abbie's youngsters - I told you didn't I? That mondays & wednesdays they are in my room from 2:15 to 3:00 - while mine are in domestic science & manual training. They work so hard with the arm movements - some of them stick out their tongues so far! Then Tuesdays & Thursdays at the same hour I have drawing with mine. They have been printing a motto which looks pretty well.

Yesterday was an uncertain sort of a day - after school just as I got to the house Evelyn came down the steps bag in hand - hat & coat. "Sevierville?" I asked. "Yes" - she said - "Dr. Massey came up this way so am going in & back tomorrow - come on as ways." Dawn at the foot of
our road was the old Ford run about & Dr. Massey - Emily went along too. He is such a big man - but we all piled in. I sat on the floor with the door swinging open so that my fair feet could rest on the running board. We went up the Roaring Fork road to the ford - (where I took the picture of the youngsters) - as he was going back via Booger Town!

Lulu May McCarter's family live near the ford so we alighted after a delightfully muddy jolty ride of a mile or more & made a short call - I had a letter from Lulu May who is away at school in Ohio & wanted to tell them about it. We stopped at the hotel on the way back to see Josie Trentham a girl who works there & ask her to tell fortunes at our Halloween party. Mr. Huff arrived just as we were leaving so he brought us back in his Ford to the foot of the lane again. Oh yes - we met a soldier lad just back from a year in France on his way home up Roaring Fork about six miles. He stopped & talked with us quite a spell - so pleased to see U.S.A. again. Imagine he is some changed mountain boy all right. Today I haven't done much besides teach - got home late & found Emily making fudge & Aunt Lizzie starting supper - Dashed off a letter to the Glasier's & had supper about five! Abbie came in to get some candy & visit - There is so much coming & going & talking (Evelyn is an inveterate talker) that the time sometimes is frittered away. She didn't get back from Sevierville after all. Have had to play for assembly several times lately and do not particularly enjoy it. We wish you could come for a visit! Couldn't we manage it? Was interested in the clippings - and hope to hear about Aurora Club & University - Club doings soon. It's all right about the Arrow as you very well know! Send it to me some time soon. Know the youngsters must be darling - Had such a nice letter from Nellie yesterday - the coats are lovely. To try swimming! I had to laugh when I read it - it goes to prove what a modern grandmother you are doesn't it? Give my fond regards to Miss Paucost! Am glad you have started to fix the house - Hope pa has finally received my letters - said none had come the last I heard from him - one should have been there the time he first arrived -
Lots & lots of love to you
